'''Buster Benton''' (July 19, 1932 – January 20, 1996)<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/buster-benton-mn0000640691/biography |title=Buster Benton | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> was an American [[blues]] guitarist and singer, who played guitar in [[Willie Dixon]]'s Blues All-Stars, and is best known for his [[solo (music)|solo]] rendition of the Dixon-penned song "Spider in My Stew."<ref name="Discography">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/spider-in-my-stew-mt0001091987 |title=Spider in My Stew - Buster Benton | Listen, Appearances, Song Review |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> He was tenacious and in the latter part of his lengthy career, despite the amputation of parts of both his legs, Benton never stopped playing his own version of [[Chicago blues]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
'''Arley Benton''' was born in [[Texarkana, Arkansas]].<ref name="russell"/>

Whilst residing in [[Toledo, Ohio]], during the mid-1950s, and having been influenced by [[Sam Cooke]] and [[B.B. King]], Benton began playing blues music.<ref name="AMG"/> By 1959, he was leading his own [[musical ensemble|band]] in [[Chicago]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 91
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> During the 1960s, local [[record label]]s, such as Melloway, Alteen, Sonic, and [[Twinight Records]] released several Benton [[single (music)|singles]], before in 1971 he joined Willie Dixon.<ref name="AMG"/> Indeed, a lack of opportunity in the early 1960s meant that Benton gave up playing professionally for several years, and he worked as an [[auto mechanic]].<ref name="russell 2">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 30
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Benton's earlier work was an amalgam of blues and [[Soul music|soul]], which he confusingly dubbed 'disco blues'. However, according to [[music journalism|Music journalist]], Bill Dahl, "in the late 1970s, when the popularity of blues music was at low ebb, Benton's recordings, particularly for Ronn Records, were a breath of fresh air."<ref name="AMG"/> 

Benton became a fixture in Dixon's Blues All-Stars for some time.<ref name="AMG"/> A 1973 album by Dixon's Blues All-Stars, featuring Benton, ''The All Star Blues World Of Maestro Willie Dixon and his Chicago Blues Band'', was issued on [[Spivey Records|Spivey]].

Dixon was credited as the songwriter of Benton's best known song, "Spider in My Stew."<ref name="Discography"/> Released on the [[Shreveport]]-based [[Jewel Records (Shreveport record label)|Jewel Records]] label, it gave Benton a modicum of fame, and his 1974 follow-up, "Money Is the Name of the Game", helped to cement his standing.<ref name="AMG"/> Benton's 1978 effort for Jewel's Ronn Records subsidiary (also titled ''Spider in My Stew'') became recognised as one of the more engaging Chicago blues albums of its time.<ref name="AMG"/> 

Benton recorded three further albums on the [[Ichiban Records|Ichiban]] label, but in comparison to his work on the Ronn label, they were uncommercial.<ref name="AMG"/> One such LP offering was 1989's, ''Money's The Name of The Game'', [[record producer|produced]] by [[Gary B.B. Coleman]].<ref name="russell 3">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 102
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Benton also issued a [[gramophone record|record]] on the Blue Phoenix label.<ref name="russell"/> Benton's fortitude did not go unnoticed. He suffered from the effects of [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] and received [[dialysis]] for the final years of his life. In addition, in 1993, part of his right leg was amputated due to poor circulation, having already lost a portion of the other some ten years previously. He soldiered on, playing his brand of the  blues up to his death.<ref name="AMG"/> However, as journalist, Tony Russell, stated in his book ''The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray'', Benton "never found another money spider".<ref name="russell"/>

Benton died in January 1996, in Chicago,<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1996.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1996 - 1997 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref> from the effects of diabetes, at age 63.

His work has appeared on a number of [[compilation album]]s, including ''Chicago Blues Festival: 1969-1986'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/chicago-blues-festival-1969-1986 |title=Chicago Blues Festival: 1969-1986: Information from |publisher=Answers.com |date=2001-09-11 |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

*1979 - ''Blues Buster'' - Red Lightnin'
*1980 - ''Buster Benton Is the Feeling'' - Ronn
*1983 - ''First Time in Europe'' - Blue Phoenix
*1988 - ''Why Me'' - [[Ichiban Records|Ichiban]]
*1989 - ''Money's the Name of The Game'' - Ichiban
*1991 - ''I Like to Hear My Guitar Sing'' - Ichiban
*1993 - ''Blues at the Top'' - Evidence Music
*1997 - ''That's the Reason'' - Ronn
*2002 - ''Blues and Trouble'' - Black & Blue<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/buster-benton-mn0000640691/discography |title=Buster Benton | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>
